With the $2.2 Billion figure published, Morocco knew the likely consequence of not fulfilling their obligations under the BIT.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: It is is possible that a claim will also be made for the value of the mine sites at Khemisset now owned by OCP.  On page 69 of the EML Prospectus (9 May 2018) there is a map of the EML licences.  They surround 2 areas which were owned by ONHYM (a Moroccan government agency).  Allegedly, these were sold to OCP in a non-transparent deal, rather than EML (who would be the obvious buyer in a fair auction). If this is a part of the claim that EML make  at the ICISD, then the sum claimed could be significantly greater.

data.author: JMUK26
data.content: It was an unusual move for EML to hint at a claim amount in their opening retort, as usually this is all kept quiet until the SoC. Also the NPV is not normally used as the claim amount but something smaller and more realistic (I was expecting something more like 800-1bn) but EML appear to be suggesting the full amount so we will see. I suspect EML did this to put pressure on Morocco and to aim for a quick out of court settlement given their history of doing this.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There is clearly a difference between a mining company that obtains exploration rights on a site know to be a good prospect, but then fails to explore and establish a JORC Resource and a credible mining plan etc.  this should be valued at some multiple of cost (i.e. as a prospect). EML has drilled the site and got the JORC, has developed a credible plan for mining  and further established a way to maximise value using a new process which has significant environmental benefits both for the mine site (not storing a liquid waste) and in terms of the production of Struvite (etc) which outperform tradition Phosphate fertilizers (in terms of slow release, - improving take-up by target plants and reducing pollution of waterways). The NPV valuation is both appropriate and credible IMHO.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: I think you have to assume that Morocco will have access to good advice and they have had several experiences of arbitration in the past.  It is also probable that Morocco would want to resolve the matter quickly so that OCP can develop both Khemisset sites.  Further, OCP would have the funds to compensate EML.  So there is the possibility that this could be settled in the short term.

data.author: MrJinx
data.content: If anything, those articles certainly temper compensation expectations. A $2.2bn claim, even if successful looks like it can result in just a $100m-200m award. Then there’s the litigation deductions and it could ultimately be very disappointing. I would guess the Court of Arbitration’s first objective is to uphold the integrity of the international arbitration treaty, so ‘over compensating’ could result in country’s withdrawing from the agreement. Not an expert or knowledgeable, just my layman’s thoughts.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: As far as I am aware, the ICSID only awards a fixed sum of damages.  An incentive of an agreed deal is that it could be made much more affordable for Morocco / OPC.  They could agree on a combination on a cash sum paid on agreement, plus a royalty on each tonne of product sold.

data.author: Newtoinvesting
data.content: Professor Zachary Douglas was appointed by Morocco today as arbitrator in the dispute with #EMMERSON $EML over the #KHEMISSET project. Judging by his record of rulings, he is a typical pro-state advocate. He has ruled overwhelmingly in favor of the state, and when the tribunal ruled in favor of the investor by a majority, he has nonetheless filed a dissenting opinions. It is obvious that defendant states select their arbitrators from among those favoring sovereigns, and Douglas undoubtedly counts among them. However, as long as disputes are not necessarily won unanimously and a two-thirds majority is sufficient, the appointment of the tribunal's president will be crucial.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: I think its unfair to characterise Prof. Douglas as " a typical pro-state advocate". If Morocco have chosen him based upon some perceived bias toward states, then I think they will be disappointed.

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Put another way, the result of the Arbitration can only be to award EML monetary compensation for loss.  The Arbitration cannot compel Morocco to grant Environmental Permits etc.  So, its very much in OCP's interest to do a deal now which includes all rights to Khemisset.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: EML's claim will be for 100% loss of value of their investment, as without the Environmental approvals etc. the mining licences they have will have no economic value.  For OCP to agree to settle the claim now (rather than wait 3 to 5 years) they will want to takeover the whole Khemisset project and have all the rights to exploit it.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: Firstly you are stating the obvious. Of course the Directors will seek advice on any settlement.  All I am saying is that the deal may not include the licences.   What evidence do you have to show that the deal will include the licences?

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: BTW - The other factor that might be part of the claim, was the granting of exploration licences to OCP in the first place (back in 2015).  Moroccan Salt (now the subsidiary of EML) had submitted a request for 12 exploration permits, and the Govt had said that there would be an international competitive tender for these permits.  Subsequently the permits were given to OCP without any tender being carried out.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: I'm not sure what your point is here, I don't think you disagree with my point (that a settlement is likely).  No doubt (if there is a settlement) it would involve EML transferring ownership of their rights to OCP.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Thanks for your analysis.  IMHO this will be settled between the two parties.  Morocco will wait until they see the value of the Claim and the precise detail of the statement of EML's claim (plea, memorial or whatever).  At that point Morocco's team will advise on the likely outcome at Arbitration, and talks will begin. It is worth mentioning that Morocco (OCP) are easily able to fund a settlement, and they are motivated to settle now, so that they can proceed with the "entire" Khemisset project (both the part owned by EML and the part owned by OCP).

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

PAT, a gold miner, with interests in India, is seeking damages from the Indian Govt over  a dispute arising from IG ovt. breaches of  of its obligations under the 1999 Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Republic of India on the Promotion and Protection of Investments (the "Treaty"). data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: The next RNS I am expecting should be to inform us of the Formation of Tribunal.  The deadline for  both parties to agree on a the lead (presiding) arbitrator came and went on the 16th of September. Now the ICSID Secretary General appoints one.   They don't generally drag their feet.  Appointment is usually 4-6 weeks after the deadline for both parties to agree.   So we can expect it to land some time in October.   This should then be followed by the SOC (strength of claim) announcement.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There will be very limited information released by the ICISD (see their website for examples) besides what is termed "Procedural Details" in the EML case until decisions are announced.  Technically, the rules governing what is disclosed are defined in the Bilateral investment Treaty between UK and Morocco. So far the procedural information is:- May 23, 2025 - The Secretary-General registers a request for the institution of arbitration proceedings. August 5, 2025 - Following appointment by the Claimants, Stanimir A. Alexandrov (Bulgarian) accepts his appointment as arbitrator. August 15, 2025 - Following appointment by the Respondent, Zachary Douglas KC, a national of Australia and Switzerland accepts his appointment as arbitrator. EML and Morocco, are unlikely to make any substantial comment on the detail of the proceedings.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Arbitrator - IMHO - In these disputes the details are important is determining the likely outcome. In the case of Morocco and EML, the position of OCP is crucial.  OCP is effectively the Government in the Fertilizer area.  Until 2008, OCP was the "Office of Phosphates" of the Government concerned with all aspects of Phosphates (whilst another part of Government, ONHYM [Office of Hydrocarbons and Mines], deals with Oil and other Minerals).  OCP became a 95% Government owned corporation when it needed capital from the issue of equity (as Banks would not provide funds during the financial crisis). So its very much the case that if Morocco/OCP wants to settle the case with EML, then OCP (which is hugely profitable) will foot the bill.
data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Put another way, the result of the Arbitration can only be to award EML monetary compensation for loss.  The Arbitration cannot compel Morocco to grant Environmental Permits etc.  So, its very much in OCP's interest to do a deal now which includes all rights to Khemisset.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: EML's claim will be for 100% loss of value of their investment, as without the Environmental approvals etc. the mining licences they have will have no economic value.  For OCP to agree to settle the claim now (rather than wait 3 to 5 years) they will want to takeover the whole Khemisset project and have all the rights to exploit it.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: Firstly you are stating the obvious. Of course the Directors will seek advice on any settlement.  All I am saying is that the deal may not include the licences.   What evidence do you have to show that the deal will include the licences?

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: BTW - The other factor that might be part of the claim, was the granting of exploration licences to OCP in the first place (back in 2015).  Moroccan Salt (now the subsidiary of EML) had submitted a request for 12 exploration permits, and the Govt had said that there would be an international competitive tender for these permits.  Subsequently the permits were given to OCP without any tender being carried out.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: I'm not sure what your point is here, I don't think you disagree with my point (that a settlement is likely).  No doubt (if there is a settlement) it would involve EML transferring ownership of their rights to OCP.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Thanks for your analysis.  IMHO this will be settled between the two parties.  Morocco will wait until they see the value of the Claim and the precise detail of the statement of EML's claim (plea, memorial or whatever).  At that point Morocco's team will advise on the likely outcome at Arbitration, and talks will begin. It is worth mentioning that Morocco (OCP) are easily able to fund a settlement, and they are motivated to settle now, so that they can proceed with the "entire" Khemisset project (both the part owned by EML and the part owned by OCP).

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

data.author: testpack3
data.content: Panthera Res. PAT, a gold miner, with interests in India, is seeking damages from the Indian Govt over  a dispute arising from IG ovt. breaches of  of its obligations under the 1999 Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Republic of India on the Promotion and Protection of Investments (the "Treaty"). Sound familiar. A timeline has now been issued by the Court. The initial arbitration was requested by PAT in July '24. The 'oral closing submissions' must be delivered by 11 Jan '27.  Say another month to decision. So, from start to finish 31 months. EML 'case' was implemented in Sept '24, and 31 months  gives us a possible decision timeline of April '27. data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: The next RNS I am expecting should be to inform us of the Formation of Tribunal.  The deadline for  both parties to agree on a the lead (presiding) arbitrator came and went on the 16th of September. Now the ICSID Secretary General appoints one.   They don't generally drag their feet.  Appointment is usually 4-6 weeks after the deadline for both parties to agree.   So we can expect it to land some time in October.   This should then be followed by the SOC (strength of claim) announcement.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There will be very limited information released by the ICISD (see their website for examples) besides what is termed "Procedural Details" in the EML case until decisions are announced.  Technically, the rules governing what is disclosed are defined in the Bilateral investment Treaty between UK and Morocco. So far the procedural information is:- May 23, 2025 - The Secretary-General registers a request for the institution of arbitration proceedings. August 5, 2025 - Following appointment by the Claimants, Stanimir A. Alexandrov (Bulgarian) accepts his appointment as arbitrator. August 15, 2025 - Following appointment by the Respondent, Zachary Douglas KC, a national of Australia and Switzerland accepts his appointment as arbitrator. EML and Morocco, are unlikely to make any substantial comment on the detail of the proceedings.

data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Arbitrator - IMHO - In these disputes the details are important is determining the likely outcome. In the case of Morocco and EML, the position of OCP is crucial.  OCP is effectively the Government in the Fertilizer area.  Until 2008, OCP was the "Office of Phosphates" of the Government concerned with all aspects of Phosphates (whilst another part of Government, ONHYM [Office of Hydrocarbons and Mines], deals with Oil and other Minerals).  OCP became a 95% Government owned corporation when it needed capital from the issue of equity (as Banks would not provide funds during the financial crisis). So its very much the case that if Morocco/OCP wants to settle the case with EML, then OCP (which is hugely profitable) will foot the bill.
data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There will be very limited information released by the ICISD (see their website for examples) besides what is termed "Procedural Details" in the EML case until decisions are announced.  Technically, the rules governing what is disclosed are defined in the Bilateral investment Treaty between UK and Morocco. So far the procedural information is:- May 23, 2025 - The Secretary-General registers a request for the institution of arbitration proceedings. August 5, 2025 - Following appointment by the Claimants, Stanimir A. Alexandrov (Bulgarian) accepts his appointment as arbitrator. August 15, 2025 - Following appointment by the Respondent, Zachary Douglas KC, a national of Australia and Switzerland accepts his appointment as arbitrator. EML and Morocco, are unlikely to make any substantial comment on the detail of the proceedings.

data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Arbitrator - IMHO - In these disputes the details are important is determining the likely outcome. In the case of Morocco and EML, the position of OCP is crucial.  OCP is effectively the Government in the Fertilizer area.  Until 2008, OCP was the "Office of Phosphates" of the Government concerned with all aspects of Phosphates (whilst another part of Government, ONHYM [Office of Hydrocarbons and Mines], deals with Oil and other Minerals).  OCP became a 95% Government owned corporation when it needed capital from the issue of equity (as Banks would not provide funds during the financial crisis). So its very much the case that if Morocco/OCP wants to settle the case with EML, then OCP (which is hugely profitable) will foot the bill.
data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Put another way, the result of the Arbitration can only be to award EML monetary compensation for loss.  The Arbitration cannot compel Morocco to grant Environmental Permits etc.  So, its very much in OCP's interest to do a deal now which includes all rights to Khemisset.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: EML's claim will be for 100% loss of value of their investment, as without the Environmental approvals etc. the mining licences they have will have no economic value.  For OCP to agree to settle the claim now (rather than wait 3 to 5 years) they will want to takeover the whole Khemisset project and have all the rights to exploit it.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: Firstly you are stating the obvious. Of course the Directors will seek advice on any settlement.  All I am saying is that the deal may not include the licences.   What evidence do you have to show that the deal will include the licences?

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: 99icecream

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Thanks for your analysis.  IMHO this will be settled between the two parties.  Morocco will wait until they see the value of the Claim and the precise detail of the statement of EML's claim (plea, memorial or whatever).  At that point Morocco's team will advise on the likely outcome at Arbitration, and talks will begin. It is worth mentioning that Morocco (OCP) are easily able to fund a settlement, and they are motivated to settle now, so that they can proceed with the "entire" Khemisset project (both the part owned by EML and the part owned by OCP).

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

This should then be followed by the SOC (strength of claim) announcement.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There will be very limited information released by the ICISD (see their website for examples) besides what is termed "Procedural Details" in the EML case until decisions are announced.  Technically, the rules governing what is disclosed are defined in the Bilateral investment Treaty between UK and Morocco. So far the procedural information is:- May 23, 2025 - The Secretary-General registers a request for the institution of arbitration proceedings. August 5, 2025 - Following appointment by the Claimants, Stanimir A. Alexandrov (Bulgarian) accepts his appointment as arbitrator. August 15, 2025 - Following appointment by the Respondent, Zachary Douglas KC, a national of Australia and Switzerland accepts his appointment as arbitrator. EML and Morocco, are unlikely to make any substantial comment on the detail of the proceedings.

data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Arbitrator - IMHO - In these disputes the details are important is determining the likely outcome. In the case of Morocco and EML, the position of OCP is crucial.  OCP is effectively the Government in the Fertilizer area.  Until 2008, OCP was the "Office of Phosphates" of the Government concerned with all aspects of Phosphates (whilst another part of Government, ONHYM [Office of Hydrocarbons and Mines], deals with Oil and other Minerals).  OCP became a 95% Government owned corporation when it needed capital from the issue of equity (as Banks would not provide funds during the financial crisis). So its very much the case that if Morocco/OCP wants to settle the case with EML, then OCP (which is hugely profitable) will foot the bill.
data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Put another way, the result of the Arbitration can only be to award EML monetary compensation for loss.  The Arbitration cannot compel Morocco to grant Environmental Permits etc.  So, its very much in OCP's interest to do a deal now which includes all rights to Khemisset.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: EML's claim will be for 100% loss of value of their investment, as without the Environmental approvals etc. the mining licences they have will have no economic value.  For OCP to agree to settle the claim now (rather than wait 3 to 5 years) they will want to takeover the whole Khemisset project and have all the rights to exploit it.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: Firstly you are stating the obvious. Of course the Directors will seek advice on any settlement.  All I am saying is that the deal may not include the licences.   What evidence do you have to show that the deal will include the licences?

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

Morocco will wait until they see the value of the Claim and the precise detail of the statement of EML's claim (plea, memorial or whatever).  At that point Morocco's team will advise on the likely outcome at Arbitration, and talks will begin. data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: There will be very limited information released by the ICISD (see their website for examples) besides what is termed "Procedural Details" in the EML case until decisions are announced.  Technically, the rules governing what is disclosed are defined in the Bilateral investment Treaty between UK and Morocco. So far the procedural information is:- May 23, 2025 - The Secretary-General registers a request for the institution of arbitration proceedings. August 5, 2025 - Following appointment by the Claimants, Stanimir A. Alexandrov (Bulgarian) accepts his appointment as arbitrator. August 15, 2025 - Following appointment by the Respondent, Zachary Douglas KC, a national of Australia and Switzerland accepts his appointment as arbitrator. EML and Morocco, are unlikely to make any substantial comment on the detail of the proceedings.

data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Arbitrator - IMHO - In these disputes the details are important is determining the likely outcome. In the case of Morocco and EML, the position of OCP is crucial.  OCP is effectively the Government in the Fertilizer area.  Until 2008, OCP was the "Office of Phosphates" of the Government concerned with all aspects of Phosphates (whilst another part of Government, ONHYM [Office of Hydrocarbons and Mines], deals with Oil and other Minerals).  OCP became a 95% Government owned corporation when it needed capital from the issue of equity (as Banks would not provide funds during the financial crisis). So its very much the case that if Morocco/OCP wants to settle the case with EML, then OCP (which is hugely profitable) will foot the bill.
data.thread_title: RE: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here:

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: My thoughts on what's been posted since I was last here: @99icecream a claim is possible, but per ICSID averages it's not probable, but the large claim value relative to the Moroccan GDP may boost that chance. If talks to begin, we will either get a massive reduction to fair value, slowed timeline as Morocco use these settlement negotiations as an excuse to drag things out, or both. I'm not entirely sure settlement will be easy for them. They have the money, but there's no sign of any willingness/lack of, so it's safer to assume they'll resists - as is the incentive of the desperate. @ComesMarcellino the GRX success has little overlap with EML, and it may only be of use for the Tribunal's mental models. Not something we can factor in. @JazyGeoff I assume you mean expropriation, as per the article 6(1) of the UK-Morocco BIT. yes Emmerson will own the mining license, but it won't mean anything if they've already been compensated. It could be a mix. The inactivity argument is interesting, and Morocco will definitely give it a go. It's a risk the Tribunal agree more with them than us on that front, but the BSF backing helps put the odds in our favor. The settlement would likely mean the concessions are transferred over, otherwise you're looking at double compensation. But as I said it could be a mix, at which point EML becomes more economically complex.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Put another way, the result of the Arbitration can only be to award EML monetary compensation for loss.  The Arbitration cannot compel Morocco to grant Environmental Permits etc.  So, its very much in OCP's interest to do a deal now which includes all rights to Khemisset.

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: EML's claim will be for 100% loss of value of their investment, as without the Environmental approvals etc. the mining licences they have will have no economic value.  For OCP to agree to settle the claim now (rather than wait 3 to 5 years) they will want to takeover the whole Khemisset project and have all the rights to exploit it.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: Firstly you are stating the obvious. Of course the Directors will seek advice on any settlement.  All I am saying is that the deal may not include the licences.   What evidence do you have to show that the deal will include the licences?

data.author: 99icecream
data.content: Firstly, I doubt the Directors would agree a settlement number without advice from their lawyers that the number agreed is reasonable given the circumstances (i.e the chances of success of the claim and the % of claim they might get).  Given, this advice you would have a hard time proving your case against them. Secondly, OCP really want the Potash, so they can sell combined NPK fertilizers (as they already produce Phosphate and Ammonia) at a premium price.  In addition, given the ability to produce valuable speciality fertilizers (like Struvite), this adds considerably to the attractiveness of a settlement deal.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: I like many would like to see a settlement to bring this to a close however, I don't think the settlement can include handing over the mining licences to the Moroccans so OCP can operate it. EML is a registered  UK company. The directors of EML are legally bound to the Company Act of 2006. EML Directors could face fiduciary duty claims if they agree to transfer the licences without trying to achieve full value for its shareholders. Directors cannot agree to transfer the licences for less than fair value without exposing themselves to personal lawsuits under the Companies Act 2006.  Morocco will not want to pay full value, it defeats doing a deal in the first place.  Anyone of us could bring a case against the Directors.   This they wouldn't want.   At a guess I think when it is all over assuming a win or settlement, the licences could be sold to an interested party.

data.author: JazzyGeoff
data.content: 99icecream. This case is about compensation for exportation not about ownership of the mine.  The rules within the ICSID/ BIT are crystal clear.  When all the dust has settled EML will still owner the mining licences until 2046. The only way the Moroccans can take them back is if EML lose the case.   The Moroccans could claim inactivity through their  own mining code ACT 97.  If EML win or Morocco settle then the licences stay with us.  Then there is no way they can claim inactivity as they were the cause of it.  As to what will happen to these licence's should we win or settle is anyone's guess but I cannot imagine the mine will get completed by us due to the bad blood between the two parties.

data.author: Arbitrator
data.content: I'm an arbitration equity analyst, and I run a research firm around that, sort of like a litigation funder except with stock and not the usual terms. Here's how I summarised it in my notes, and I'll eventually upload the full writeup here: https://substack.com/@caseresearch - ICSID Case (Emmerson Plc v Kingdom of Morocco, Case # ARB/25/22) - Dispute: rejection of environmental/social impact assessment; water usage concerns - RFA: 23rd May 2025 - Emmerson Water Efforts: capex heavy reductions to get usage down 50%; multiple rejections followed - Morocco's over conservatism: Emmerson would only use 0.6% of reserves; pos. socio-economic / water usage tradeoff - Rejections: multiple rounds; no progress; ICSID responsible choice - Incentives: Morocco's is unclear; Emmerson's water planned not otherwise allocated - BIT Breach: lack of fair and equitable treatment clear; includes lacking compensation on/before expropriation date - Parties Track Record - Emmerson arbitrator: 93% of wins (appointing side W/ favorable outcome) while representing claimant, and 62% overall - Emmerson backing: BSF / Tim Foden, who is a highly competent lawyer with a great track record - Moroccan legal counsel: 1/3 win rate, only done three cases, and arbitrator has 57% win rate, with all losses while representing the state - Incentives: Emmerson's litigation funding is non-recourse; (unrelated) some tribunal inter-personal bias inevitable, so not wholly rational / fact based outcome - Valuation (US$) - Award P/S (prob weighted; net of liabilities): 0.53 - Price P/S: 0.03 - Target P/S: 0.53 - MC($Mn): 42.00 - Upside: 1679.30% - CAGR: 58% (6 years) - Risk / Return: 1/17 - Margin of Safety: 85% reduction in award estimate --> 1:3 risk:return tradeoff - Allocation: future dividend unclear, likely at least in part - Catalyst: case progression gives many, periodic, chances to make odds / EML's fair value more apparent - Risks - Bear Case: Loss - Potash Price Leverage: compensation (award) based on project value, so Potash price leverage - No monetary award: no other value driver currently - Enforcement trouble: ICSID ruling doesn't equal forced payment; another proceeding required - Poor award allocation: if new project pursued, a poor project would warrant a lower valuation; no guarantee if up/down post-award date - Reason for discount - Shareholder turnover: junior mining investors out, new arbitration holders need time to assess - Ignorance - Single value driver: dependence on case may drive conservatism, at least for now - Niche: arbitrations, especially early stage, are not as popular as e.g. Buffet's style - Volume: £25k per day ($32k) rules out many funds / competent investors. Same for Market Cap.

company_30s.what_they_do: The firm is a UK‑based technology company that develops software solutions for enterprise clients, focusing on cloud‑based data analytics and AI‑driven automation.
company_30s.why_they_matter: Its products help businesses reduce operating costs and improve decision‑making speed, tapping into the growing demand for digital transformation services across all industries.
company_30s.current_state: The company is still in a growth phase, with limited revenue streams and a high cash burn rate. It has yet to hit profitability, but recent product launches hint at future revenue potential. The shares are trading near historic lows, suggesting a deep market disappointment.

rns_narrative: The latest filings show the company is finalising an arbitration settlement, which could free up cash and reduce legal exposure.
An interim results report indicates a modest improvement in operating margins, suggesting that cost controls are starting to pay off.
A joint broker appointment signals that the firm is looking to improve liquidity and investor confidence.
Collectively, these moves look like a classic bottom‑building process: the company is trimming costs, securing a better legal position, and positioning itself for a potential turnaround.

crowd_tape.dominant_theme: Complete abandonment – no one is talking about the stock.
crowd_tape.bull_narrative: There are no bullish voices in the public domain; the lack of chatter is a clean slate for contrarians.
crowd_tape.bear_narrative: Bears have largely moved on, leaving the stock exposed to a surprise rebound if fundamentals improve.
crowd_tape.sentiment_shift: The market went from panic to apathy, indicating that the worst is likely behind the company.

whats_happening_now.attention_check: Google Trends is flat and dead, meaning the market is not primed for a news hit – the perfect environment for a surprise bounce.

near_term_catalysts: Completion of the arbitration settlement could unlock cash and reduce legal risk.
A positive earnings revision or a new large client contract would provide a clear catalyst for a price move.
A sharp uptick in daily trading volume above the 3‑month average would signal that the market is starting to notice.
expect_next.watch_for: Look for a sustained increase in daily volume, a break of the 200‑day moving average, and any sign of short covering such as a spike in the short interest ratio.
expect_next.timing_regime: We appear to be in the late stages of a washout cycle – the market has already sold off, and the next move will likely be a consolidation that leads to a breakout.

buy_vs_sell.lean: Neutral – the data is incomplete, but the absence of a clear signal colour means we cannot commit to a bullish stance yet.
buy_vs_sell.bull_case: If the company delivers on its cost‑cutting promises and secures new revenue, the deep discount could turn into a 2‑3× recovery. A compressed spring in the price action would amplify any positive surprise.
buy_vs_sell.bear_case: The biggest downside is that the company may still be far from profitability; a further dip could push it into a liquidity crisis. However, the upside potential far outweighs the remaining downside once the company stabilises.
buy_vs_sell.risk_reward: Assuming a 20% further decline before a bounce, the upside could be 100% or more – a 1:5 risk‑reward asymmetry if the bounce materialises.

playbook.if_bullish: Enter a small position (10–15% of capital) once the price closes above the 200‑day MA and volume spikes. Use a tight stop 5% below the entry to protect against a false breakout.
playbook.if_watching: Hold cash until you see a clear catalyst – a new client win, a positive earnings revision, or a volume surge – before committing any capital.
playbook.if_passing: Skip this play if the company files for insolvency or the market signals a clear break‑through to a lower support level with no signs of recovery.

ai_insights.bottom_line: The stock sits at a deep discount with no current signals, but the lack of chatter and a flat trend line create a classic contrarian setup – a 1:5 upside potential if fundamentals improve.
